data.text: Will likely get one on my next bike (for Trekking). They add roughly $1000+ to the price, so be aware. A Rohloff should be perfectly fine, if you don't want to make that leap. The gear range on the Pinion is tops, but you pay a slight weight penalty. It's all tradeoffs.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: There really isn't a weight penalty between the Rohloff and the Pinion C1.12, or any real price difference either. The Pinion C1.12 has two fewer gears but 74% more range. Step up to the P-series Pinions and the Rohloff wins on weight and price.

data.text: Yeah, the P1.18 has a bit more on the top end but not much. You are mostly just getting the smaller gear jumps as an advantage. However, now you are looking at about twice the price (just for the gearbox) and a not-insignifcant amount of extra weight. I guess it depends on how much of a cadence junkie you are. With my time on the C1.12 so far, I don't think I mind the gear jumps at all. However, I have not done any loaded riding on my new bike yet either so maybe I will feel differently once I do.

data.text: I have a Pinion/Gates setup. There's no noticeable difference in resistance! I love my bike. The gears are smooth, shift easily and quiet. In my case it's the C1.12 gearbox . 12 gears, 600% ratio from 1 to 12. My bike also has a Gates Carbon Belt drive so no chain lube, no broken links, no worn cassettes, no bent derailleurs and no fiddley cable adjustments. I LOVE this bike! BTW, it's a Priority 600. Check them out online: https://www.prioritybicycles.com/products/the600

data.text: I use a pinion p1.18 with a belt drive and has worked amazingly for 6 years and nearly 40,000km. The belt is still original but the cogs are on the second generation. I bought the bike from a local bike shop so that if anything happened, they could service it. It only had an oil change every year and after 5 years, it had an inspection by Pinion to extend the warranty for another 5 years. Other than that, no need to clean or service anything on the way. I take a spare belt on trips- just in case, but no incidents at all.
